comments.commentBody: Well it seems certain that Roberts does not see it that way. For him the analysis boils down easily to a simple bromide. "The way to stop discrimination on the basis of race is to stop discriminating on the basis of race."  Parents v Seattle School District.  For him resolving our deeply complex and historic racial conundrums is simple and easily reduced to this judicially manufactured shibboleth. We must merely cease taking any account race in formulating solutions. This amounts to an unwise and unfair majoritarian "solution" which shuts out a whole and distinct group of affected voices and effectively puts occam's razor in charge of our most complex, most painful and intractable social issue. Roberts does a huge disservice to all of us by trying to package the solutions to our racial divisions into this frightenly simple bromide. Sotomayer could have used her opinion here to make clear that Roberts seemingly fair but  stunningly concrete view of race is an actual  impediment to to achieving meaningful solutions.

It seems like fraud to us non-lawyers. Your 2cd paragraph says it all. I can't wait till someone tries to sell us a memo directly linking Obama to knowledge of this defect and impending lawsuits before the bailout. Whether or not he did know it will sound like he did. And likely at his level he wasn't told to protect him. Which in itself shouldn't happen.

All that said, I think it behooves us as a country to keep our manufacturing bases going. We may well need them again in the future to tool up for defense reasons, or even other domestic reasons like building high speed trains.

If they knew about the magnitude of the defect but didn't disclose it in bankruptcy, isn't that fraud and invalidate the bankruptcy?

Whatever the case, people are really getting fed up with big corporations and the rich getting every break imaginable while everyone else gets none.

So, would you have let a million people, who were employees of GM, employees of suppliers of GM, dealerships associated with GM, retirees from GM and their suppliers, and small business people who lived in and had businesses in GM towns where GM and supplier employees did business, lose those jobs and businesses in the height of the worst economic time since 1929? Remember too, those same suppliers also supply parts to Ford, Toyota, Nissan, etc. We are not just talking the Midwest here, but also many other parts our world. Yes, the UAW supported Obama, and union members kept certain benefits and pay, but also lost thousands of jobs in the process. Everyone lost in the bankruptcy, yet it was much preferable to the disaster-at-hand that would have happened. Now, I can't imagine anyone with any ability to reason that could not have figured that if an "old GM" was created in bankruptcy to clean up old buildings, environmental messes and old liabilities, that there actually were old lingering and probably severe problems associated with GM. No way am I defending GM in the recall/liability situation. I am saying that your solution of letting GM fail might have been soul-satisfying for you and many others, but it would have been an absolute disaster in 2009 for the world's economy, to say nothing of the national economy. Remember too, there are tens of thousands of workers & retirees who had absolutely nothing to do with the coverup or the bankruptcy.
Taking responsibility doesn't apply to the little people either.
G.M seems to want to ensure that a sizable percentage of the American public will never buy from them. Never.

Worker, retirees, businessmen in communities associated with GM, and their worldwide suppliers... Just throw them all under the bus when the majority of them had nothing to do with the problems you mentioned, other than to build the cars in the manner that engineering and management prescribed, and those cars you mentioned were built 30 years ago. I note you are from Florida, Cindy. No GM factories in Florida, other than a service parts location that used to be in Jacksonville, so it's real easy to not care about thousands of workers in the Midwest. Btw, the new GM, unlike its forerunner from the years you mentioned, is building good cars now; even Consumer Reports admits this. Are the present day workers who had nothing to do with 1985 to be penalized? As I said before, GM was wrong, wrong, wrong to not recall the Cobalts. Let's find the guilty parties and subject them to the fullest extent of punishment we can. Fine GM, heavily. Remember though, most GM employees, past and present, had nothing to do with this fiasco, no more than a resident of Florida whose paycheck is not dependent upon GM.
... and both are only now having their malfeasance aired, after the US government sold its holdings and made its profit.
if they lose your point will be moot.

Millions of "the common folk" signed fraudulent mortgage, credit, job, and other applications and got away with money they did not deserve, without even a slap on the wrist. Or, have you already forgotten? Would you also argue that the government can go back to them and squeeze them for a percentage of everything they've earned since their crimes?

Andy Hain of Carmel is comparing applies and oranges. He writes that millions of people "signed fraudulent mortgage, credit, job, and other applications and got away with money they did not deserve, without even a slap on the wrist." But a huge percentage of them signed fraudulent mortgage applications without understanding all that fine print--and then lost their homes and all the money they'd put in as down payment, repairs, etc. The GM executives knew what they were doing. They didn't just get away with undeserved money; their actions cost innocent lives.

Yoandel,

Lets assume for a moment the behavior of the old and new GM was reprehensible and criminal regarding this switch. The bankruptcy process was engineered by the administration solely for the benefit of GM managers and union employees. All the bondholders, shareholders and taxpayers took a multibillion dollar bath courtesy of the government. So will the victims of this corporate scam. By the way, the new CEO is neck deep in this whole mess.

So, the real criminals here are a) the politicians and their enablers who engineered this bankruptcy and stuck it to the bondholders, shareholders and taxpayers; b) the management employees and the c) UAW and its leadership and members. The victims of this bad switch are just the latest to be harmed by Government Motors.

Think about that next time the government gets the bright idea to bail out a company.

GM has two choices:

To as a corporation come clean, indicate who (and when) authorized, aided, abetted, approved, pursued, and blessed corporate policies that allowed unsafe cars on the road --and resulted in the injury and death of many. If GM does this, then those executives should be going to jail.

Otherwise, GM should be considered a corporate person that committed crimes --and must then be forced to make these victims whole. And if this means separating GM into pieces, and selling their property and good to their competitors --so be it.

Everyday the common folk are faced with jail penalties and restitution. It is high time that GM be subjected to the same standard.

Another reason why I wouldn't consider buying GM. Not only did it cover up its design flaw, stonewall victims, and now a preemptive move to head off lawsuits? If only they spend all those energy and resources into improve its cars and operations, it would have been in a much better position than its sorry state now.

People failing to heed what economics tells them is not the same as economics failing.

In fact, as Dr. Krugman's column documents, economics told us exactly what our problem was, and what the proven solution would be. So how then did economics fail us?
The point is textbook economics did not fail. It was ignored. Textbook economics predicted the outcome precisely.

It's important to note that "economics" didn't prescribe the solution Dr Krugman advocates. Keynesian Economics prescribed the solution he advocates. Economics 101 has been equivalent with Keynesian Economics for a long time now.

My point is simply that there are alternative economic theories, like the Austrian version advocated by many Republicans.

Economics is a social science that attempts to model the whole world. This requires enormous assumptions and the results will be affected by the assumptions.

Given the political power and economic benefits people can obtain if their version of economic reality is advanced, it's no wonder the discipline fails when it's needed most. Heck, climate science is based on observation of the physical world and a lot of Americans think it's hogwash.
Sorry, congress clearly DOES represent the Amercian People. At least the American people willing to vote, and clearly a majority chose the congress critters we got.

I don't think economics failed us and I don't believe that what "the little people" thought about national debt was relevant. Both were ignored by firms (big banks, investment houses and rating agencies), their buddies who convinced Congress to bail them out and give them virtually unlimited interest free money (Paulson, Geithner, Summers) and politicians dependent upon legal bribery to be re-elected.
Those folks got rich when they created the bubble and then made a lot more money by using public monies to buy up distressed stocks and other assets.
Congress clearly does not represent the American people. Americans are still mad about the bailout but not one executive of those firms has gone to jail for falsifying mortgages and other crimes that caused the bubble, and the firms were not forced to take a major haircut. And Congress will not pass into law many policies that surveys show a large majority of Americans support.
This is unlikely to change until we force Congress to pass laws and modify the First Amendment to prevent any private expenses that favor political campaigns. The oligarchs and their lobbyists have Congress in their pocket.

lt sounds like you have a pretty low regard for education and teachers. Might I guess that you work in the private sector, are a Republican, and have no children in public schools?

Your priorities and your figures are bizarre to put it nicely.

But most tellingly, if your friend the teacher really said s/he is in it for the money, well, guess what? The new contract will also make it easier for schools to fire low-performing hacks like the"last teacher" you spoke to. It is teachers like those who stain the many passionate teachers who are in it for the pure love of the work.

And p-s.: private sector employment DOES offer those and more benefits- unless you are talking about working in a mailroom. Why the bitter tone?
Great answer. Thank you- teaching is its own reward but we still have to live, and yes everyone forgets how important education is.

Wrong... Productive ppl pay the taxes.  You can't have any of the above without them.  In fact the coffers would be dry now - and teachers and other municipal workers would be getting laid off instead of a raise!  That's exactly what has happened in other places.

I love the "just wait until everyone moves to New Jersey posts here."

Please! Go! It'll drive down rents for those of us who actually work in the city, so that we can actually live in the city in which we work.

The DeBlasio will have accomplished three of his goals. A stronger working class and middle class. Affordable housing. And an improved public education system capable of attracting the best teachers, supported by the wider, deeper, tax base of hard-working New Yorkers.

Expose the lies and propaganda drones, folks! This will be your city when you choose to make it your city.

Before getting worked up about it, wait to see what these "raises" actually mean. It is unclear when, how and in some cases if these raises will be paid out. Nobody is getting more than a 2% raise any time soon, and no "retroactive raises" -- in other words referred compensation -- will be paid out until 2015, and that will be spread out over 5 years. At the moment the math is very fuzzy.

Perhaps if teachers had three- and five-year contracts, I'd feel some sympathy.  Sorry.  Engineers--who work as hard as any teacher, e.g., 18-hour days--can be fired in a moment if they get it wrong.  Teachers are forever.  How unfortunate for our children.

Actually, it is written in NY Labor law. Union contracts must be retroactive to the date the previous contract expired, unless the union agrees to give back money it is owed in the new contract. The teachers are not gaining the four percent raises for the two years retroactive, they are giving up two years of what they are legally owed.

Teaching is not a nine month job. Prep for the new school year starts about mid summer and often teachers take a couple of weeks to wrap up their classrooms after the end of the school year. Most younger teachers work multiple jobs and many, if not most teachers, work summer jobs.

I am always amused by those who think that teaching is an overpaid cakewalk. I would like to see those people try it, especially in a "high need" district.

I am very troubled by the idea that teachers and other NYC employees working without a contract are owed back pay. Under state law, the current contract remains in force, so employees who were due raises for promotions, seniority raises, Colas, etc still received them. So they were not hurt too bad as the status quo continued.

Where is it written that they are entitled to raises at all, let alone for prior years. Taxpayers pay teachers more every year for the same work, year after year, with the same or worse results. Where are the productivity increases that would support across the board raises?

Where are the real givebacks to help pay for this multiple-billon dollar giveaway? Is the city really going to save $1 billion from teachers getting their drugs through the mail?
Why aren't they contributing to their healthcare and pensions?

For a 9 month job with plenty of holidays, oversized benefits,limited hours, tenure and limited accountability, teachers are laughing all the way to the bank, which is still open on their way home.
If you think you can do better in the private sector, come on over. Performance evaluations, no extra pay for masters degrees or 30 credits, 401-k, and a lot less security.

It is certainly true that during the recent tough economic times, teachers looked like they have it made. Among my friends who are not teachers, several were unemployed, having lost their private industry jobs, others were worried about being laid off and were not spending on anything beyond the necessities of life, and all were envious of the pension I will receive when I retire. But I reminded them that when the economy was booming, they were all taking exotic ski vacations, buying apartments, going out on the town every weekend, and generally living the good life they could afford. I reminded them of all the times I had to turn down their invitations to join them because I could not match their budgets.

So that is the bargain that teachers and other public service workers make with society. We are like the tortoise in the fable; slow and steady. We never get to live the high flying life that that others in this city with similar years of experience, educational backgrounds and responsibility do. We plod ahead doing our jobs, teaching and caring for our students with very little fanfare or recognition. What we demand in return is a decent salary, medical benefits for our families, and a reasonable pension when we retire after 25 or 30 years. If you think teachers got the better deal in this bargain, come join us if you can handle it.

John,

You're right. You didn't have time to address Ross's column as it deserves. I wish all of you Douthat-disparagers would read his columns with an open mind. They make it clear that he considers all sides to an issue before settling on, and expressing his own view. It's not so much having the time to respond as much as it is having the will to respond - thoughtfully rather than maliciously. No one can accuse Douthat of being a knee-jerk conservative and be taken seriously.

"So many straw men," etc., but you "lack the time" to identify any of them.  You then proceed to write 188 words which demonstrate that you haven't understood a single point the author made. Douthat "seem[s] to be arguing that [Sterling's] racism is partly the fault of liberals." Seriously? Sterling's racism is never mentioned; rather, he is cited as a prominent example of someone who profits from restrictive zoning practices and limitations on housing permits that are generally supported by affluent urban liberals, but which harm the poor. Douthat's points about the human capital-enhancing effect of low-wage jobs should be clear to anyone with an open mind and a moderate capacity for "intellectual exercise."
You believe inequality is wrong?  With friends like you, liberalism doesn't need enemies.

Ross, there are so many straw man, false equivalence, red herring, and non sequitur moments in this column I know I lack the time to address this as it deserves. I'll leave it to another columnist who has the opportunity and a proper gallery in which to frame a rebuttal.

I will say that essentially you posit that the ideas opposing unequality are empty and you imply, strongly, should be dismissed.

You don't say you believe inequality is wrong. You do imply that you favor the opposite position, although the premises for that argument seem to be an unsupported assertion that Conservatives haven't been proven wrong.

Nor do you reach a conclusion that seems to tie up whatever argument you're making.

In short, you seem to be saying, correct me if I'm wrong, that Liberals are wrong, Liberals are part of the problem, Liberals aggravate the problem they help create, and in the end, since you don't propose any challengeable, testable solutions, you seem to be saying simply, leave everything alone.

Of course, I have no idea what this has to do with Sterling being a racist, except that you seem to be arguing that his racism is partly the fault of the Liberals.

Tomorrow you may go back to writing about Jesus and Roman Catholicism neither subject which you're likely to make any clearer than you did this one in this articulate, but ultimately academic intellectual exercise.
.

I recall that we did cut deficits, and generated a SURPLUS before Bush and the Republicans decided that a surplus was dangerous, and we needed to cut taxes and enter into two wars. Voila, big deficits.

I have found it difficult to discuss the federal debt with those people who confuse a government’s debt (in dollars) with personal debt and try to use kitchen table ideas to understand the economy. For example, such folks are fond of pointing out that the debt must eventually be paid off. They never tell me why this is the case, even when I point out that the debt has been paid off only once in American history (1835) and that was followed by one of the longest depressions in our history.

There have been six periods in our history when we have balanced the budget and had a surplus for more than three years. For example after World War I, we had surpluses from 1920 to 1930 and reduced the debt by almost 40 percent. There have also been six depressions in our history, and each one happened right on the heels of one of the periods of debt reduction. For example, we all know what happened in 1929.
On the other hand, after World War II, we had 27 years of mostly deficit spending and almost doubled the debt, but we had great prosperity. For example, the real median household income surged 74 percent. While paying down the debt seems to have only produced disasters, I cannot find a period when too much debt has hurt us.

These are the facts one should keep in mind when one thinks about the debt. Or we can keep doing the same things over and over and expecting different results.

A couple of issues, the ability of governments to spend during times of recession is dependent on them cutting deficits during expansion, we did no such thing. And so, expanding balance sheets even further, does bring more risk. I would agree with Mr. Krugman except that before then, our government just kept on expanding spending, no matter what. We still don't spend enough on what's important in helping the economy grow on a long term basis, infrastructure. Instead we spend it on subsides, our war machine, and a medical industry which is the most extortionate in the developed world.

And lets not forget, we had the examples in Europe, whether they fit our economic model or not, of moving towards bankruptcy. The public isn't knowledgeable enough to understand all the differences and since economists themselves behave more like radical religious leaders than confident wise men, asking us to "trust" you, seems a bit much to ask. Economics is more of a religion than the science Mr. Krugman presents it to be. Overstating it's accuracy and ability to alleviate all problems within a market economy leads me to trust Mr. Krugman less rather than more.

Silver instantly became my favorite major sports commisioner, not that there was much competition. There are a lot of undercurrents to the story - one that stuck out for me is the plantation mentality that Sterling exhibited. I don't know how it is in NC, Leapy, but it's fairly common down here among small business owners.

They provide good jobs, pay decently and often even help out employees with loans and other things, but the focus has to be totally on what they are doing for their employees, not what their employees are doing for them and gratitude is a requisite. It can apply to both white and black employees, but it's surprising how often most of the employees are black.

Hardly the worst manifestation of subtle racism - really largely beneficial - but the connection to the romantic, Gone With the Wind view of slavery is evident, at least from where I sit. It's the subtle things like this that are going to be the last to go, IMHO.

RiA, to some extent, I'd say it's a generation thing, though it isn't a threshhold cut-off, rather a diminution over time.

I'll tell you a story: We had this one patient, a very nice person of fine character, about 40 yo BM [as they say], who had sustained massive injury to his lower leg in his job as a railroad worker. It was a difficult treatment, requiring sequential bone grafting, soft tissue flaps, etc, and things did not go well because of the severe crush component. When non-union with bone infection ultimately set in, amputation was the only recourse, but this fellow remained hopeful, did his best, didn't complain, despite the pain and the major life changes. The doc who was his main surgeon [originally from WVa] thought very highly of him, I know, so I was moderately stunned when, after one clinic visit, this doc said of the patient, in commendation: "He's a credit to his race."
